questions.text: A 45-year-old female came to the ophthalmologist with complaints of sudden decrease in vision in left eye and pain with movement of eye. On examination, the pupil showed RAPD in left eye and colour vision assessment revealed a red-green deficit. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Optic neuritis

 

Option A:

 

  • Optic neuritis presents with marked decrease in visual acuity.

  • Loss of red-green colour vision is a common symptom of Optic nerve disease.

  • Pupillary defect – Marcus Gunn pupil (RAPD: suggestive of defect in optic nerve or retina)

 

 

  • Most common cause of Optic neuritis in adults in Demyelinating diseases, and among them is Multiple sclerosis (most common in middle-aged females).

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Papilledema:

 

  • Description: Papilledema is the swelling of the optic disc due to increased intracranial pressure. It usually affects both eyes.

  • Relevance to Case: While papilledema can cause visual symptoms, it does not typically present with sudden vision loss or pain with eye movement. RAPD is not a characteristic finding in papilledema.

 

Option C. Retinal Detachment:

 

  • Description: Retinal detachment involves the separation of the neurosensoryretina from its Retinal Pigment Epithelium. Symptoms include floaters, flashes of light, and a "curtain" over part of the field of vision.

  • Relevance to Case: The sudden decrease in vision could suggest retinal detachment, but the pain with eye movement and RAPD are not typical features of this condition. Also, retinal detachment does not usually affect color vision.

 

Option D. CRAO (Central Retinal Artery Occlusion):

 

  • Description: CRAO is an occlusion of the central retinal artery leading to acute, painless vision loss in one eye.

  • Relevance to Case: The sudden loss of vision is consistent with CRAO, but the presence of pain with eye movement is not typical associated with CRAO.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sudden decrease in vision, pain with movement of the eye, RAPD, and a red-green color vision deficit are classic signs of Optic Neuritis. MRI is the imaging modality of choice and treatment is pulse IV Methylprednisolone for 3 days followed by oral corticosteroids.

 

REF: KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5TH EDITION pg.no: 314

questions.text: The type of optic atrophy seen in this condition is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Consecutive

 

Option C:

 

  • The fundus picture shows retinitis pigmentosa.

  • There occurs consecutive optic atrophy characterized by waxy pallor of the optic disc.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Consecutive optic neuropathy is a form of optic nerve damage resulting as a consequence of pathologies of retina and uvea. It is characterized by progressive axonal loss leading to optic atrophy, visual impairment, and optic disc pallor on examination. Management focuses on treating the underlying cause and supporting vision with aids if necessary.

 

REF: KANSKI 9TH EDITION PAGE 753

questions.text: A patient presented with a sudden decrease in vision in right eye. While assessing his pupils, when light was shone in the left eye, both pupils constricted and when light was shone in the right eye, both pupils dilated. The likely abnormality is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Marcus Gunn pupil

 

Option C:

 

  • This is a form of paradoxical response of a pupil to light.

  • Marcus Gunn pupil is characterized by a relative afferent pupillary defect.

  • Causes: Retinal disease, Optic nerve disease, Glaucoma, Trauma.

  • It is detected via SWINGING FLASHLIGHT TEST.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Wernicke’s Pupil: if a very bright but small beam of light such as that produced by a slit lamp is shined on the nonseeing hemiretina of a patient with damage to the optic chiasm or optic tract and then is shined on the seeing hemiretina, it is possible to see that the pupil reacts better when the light shines on the seeing hemiretina than when it shines on the nonseeing retina.

 

Option B. Horner’s Pupil: This is a part of Horner's syndrome, which includes ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis on the affected side. The pupil in Horner's syndrome is smaller on the affected side but reacts normally to light and accommodation. This is not consistent with the described findings.

 

Option D. Adie’s Pupil: This involves a tonic pupil that is larger than the other and reacts poorly to light but may have a better near response. It's usually caused by damage to the postganglionic fibers of the parasympathetic innervation of the eye. This does not match the clinical picture of an RAPD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient presenting with a sudden decrease in vision in one eye and an observed pupil response where shining light in the unaffected eye causes both pupils to constrict, but shining it in the affected eye causes both to dilate, the likely diagnosis is a Marcus Gunn pupil (Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect), indicative of asymmetric optic nerve dysfunction.

 

REF: KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5TH EDITION pg.no: 312

questions.text: A patient undergoing perimetry has the following visual field defect. What is the pupillary abnormality expected in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Wernicke’s pupil

 

Option D.

 

  • The picture shows right homonymous hemianopia.

  • Site of lesion – left optic tract.

  • This is associated with Wernicke’s pupil.

 

 

 

Wernicke Pupil

 

When the optic chiasm is bisected sagittally, the nasal halves of each retina become insensitive to light so that there is not only a bitemporal hemianopia but also a bitemporal pupillary hemiakinesia; that is, light falling on the nasal retina of either eye will fail to produce a pupillary constriction. Thus, if a very bright but small beam of light such as that produced by a slit lamp is shined on the nonseeing hemiretina of a patient with damage to the optic chiasm or optic tract and then is shined on the seeing hemiretina, it is possible to see that the pupil reacts better when the light shines on the seeing hemiretina than when it shines on the nonseeing retina.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Argyll Robertson Pupil: This is a condition where pupils are small and irregular but do not constrict when exposed to bright light (light-near dissociation). They do, however, constrict with accommodation. It is classically associated with neurosyphilis, particularly tabes dorsalis, and does not have a direct correlation with homonymous hemianopia.

 

Option B. Adie’s Pupil: Also known as tonic pupil, it is usually unilateral and is larger than the other pupil. It reacts poorly to light but may have a better near response. This condition is caused by damage to the postganglionic fibers of the parasympathetic innervation of the eye and is not related to visual field defects.

 

Option C. Marcus Gunn Pupil: Also known as a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), it is a sign of asymmetrical optic nerve dysfunction. It is detected using the swinging flashlight test. However, in homonymous hemianopia, the optic nerve function is typically preserved until the optic chiasm, so a Marcus Gunn pupil is not expected.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a case of right homonymous hemianopia, the lesion lies at the level of left optic tract, and the pupillary abnormality seen in these cases will be Wernicke’s pupil.

 

REF: KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5TH EDITION pg.no: 312

2. Walsh and Hoyt’s Clinical Neuro-Ophthalmology 6th Edition pg. No: 747

questions.text: Identify the site of lesion:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MLF

 

Option B:

 

In the picture given, primary gaze and dextroversion appears normal. In levoversion, there is defective adduction of the right eye. This is suggestive of right sided INTERNUCLEAR OPHTHALMOPLEGIA.

 

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. PPRF (Paramedian Pontine Reticular Formation) is involved in initiating horizontal eye movements, but a lesion here would not specifically cause INO.

 

Option C. Both PPRF and MLF: While lesions in these areas affect eye movement, INO is exclusively associated with a lesion in the MLF.

 

Option D. riMLF (rostral interstitial nucleus of the medial longitudinal fasciculus) is involved in vertical eye movement, not typically associated with INO.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand that Internuclear Ophthalmoplegia is specifically associated with a lesion in the MLF, which disrupts the coordination of eye movements.

Top of Form

 

REF: KANSKI 9TH EDITION PAGE 806

questions.text: A patient presented with bilateral loss of vision with normal pupillary light reflex. Ocular evaluation was found to be normal. VEP shows extinguished response. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cortical blindness

 

Option B:

 

  • The given features are suggestive of cortical blindness.
  • It is total or partial loss of vision in normal appearing eye caused by damage to brain’s occipital cortex.
  • It most commonly results from ischemia due to blockade of posterior cerebral artery.
  • Macular sparing is present in occipital lobe lesions.
  • Pupillary reactions and fundoscopy are normal.
  • Visual evoked response (VER) examination shows extinguished responses .
  • ANTON SYNDROME – denial of blindness by patients who can’t see (lack of insight).
  • RIDDOCH PHENOMENON – ability to perceive kinetic but not static targets.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Malingering: wilful ‘blind’ behaviour, i.e. feigning of symptoms. On clinical examination, no ocular or neuro-ophthalmic findings are detectable which can account for the symptoms. Multiple tests like Prism test, Worth four-dot test are devised to diagnose this condition.

 

Option C. Retrobulbar neuritis: Definitive or relative afferent pupillary defect would be present.

 

Option D. Hysterical blindness: Unlike malingering, there is little or no insight into their infirmity in these cases and may sometimes display a complete lack of concern over their incapacitating symptoms (la belle indifference). May be associated with blepharospasm and lacrimation. Visual fields are concentrically contracted.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cortical blindness is characterized by an inability to see despite normal eyes and pupillary reflexes. The disrupted cortical processing is evidenced by extinguished VEPs.

 

REF: KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5TH EDITION pg.no:328

choices.text: Junction of optic nerve and chiasma
Junction of optic chiasma and optic tract

questions.text: This site of involvement in this form of defect is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Junction of optic nerve and chiasma

 

Option B:

 

  • The visual field defect shown is Junctional scotoma of Trachoir.
  • It is the syndrome of central or paracentral defect the side of optic nerve involvement alongwith a contralateral superotemporal defect.
  • It occurs due to involvement of optic nerve fibres and contralateral inferonasal fibres looping forward in the nerve, known as Knee of Wilbrand.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Optic Nerve: Lesions of the optic nerve typically cause unilateral (one-sided) visual field loss. The pattern depends on the location and extent of the lesion but can include central scotoma (loss in the center of vision), altitudinal field loss (upper or lower half), or a complete loss of vision in one eye.

 

Option C. Optic Chiasma: Lesions at the optic chiasma, such as those caused by a pituitary adenoma, typically produce bitemporal hemianopia, where there is loss of the outer (temporal) halves of the visual field in both eyes.

 

Option D. Junction of Optic Chiasma and Optic Tract: Lesions here can lead to a contralateral homonymous hemianopia with or without macular sparing. This means that the same side (either right or left) of the visual field is lost in both eyes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lesions at this junction of optic nerve and chisama cause a junctional scotoma, which involves a central scotoma in one eye along with a superior temporal field defect in the other eye, reflecting damage to both the optic nerve of one eye and the crossing fibers from the other eye

 

REF: KANSKI 9TH EDITION PAGE 789

questions.text: A middle-aged male presented to the OPD with a head tilt to the left side. On examination, it is observed that he has right hypertropia which increases on levoversion and left head-tilt. Which of the following muscles is involved?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Left superior rectus

 

Explanation:

 

In this question, the patient presenting with left head tilt is the compensatory head position to avoid diplopia. Analysis of paretic muscle is done in primary position. Student must not get confused between head tilt at presentation and the head tilt in which the hypertropia is more.

 

  • Head tilt is a form of compensatory head posture to avoid diplopia.

  • In case of 4th nerve palsy – head tilt is towards the opposite side.

  • PARK THREE STEP TEST – allows to identify the muscle involved in patients with vertical diplopia.

 

 

The student must not try to learn the outcomes of this table. While analysing any question on Park 3 step test, it is better to draw the following diagram:

 

 

Step 1: which eye is hypertropic: The elevators of the contralateral eye are paretic or depressors of ipsilateral eye are paretic. So in this case, it is right hypertropia. Thus, contralateral LSR or  LIO or ipsilateral RSO or RIR. 

 

Step 2: Which Gaze: Draw a circle around the muscles on that side of the diagram, the gaze in which the hypertropia is more. So in this case, it is more on left gaze, thus, LSR or RSO

 

Step 3: Which head tilt: Draw a diagonal line – upper side of the line starts from the upper corner of the direction of head tilt. So in this case, left head tilt, Thus the correct answer would be LSR. 

 

Interpretation: The muscle which lies in the interjection of all the 3 steps, is the paretic muscle.

 

Other example for practice in which hypertropia is more with right head tilt. The answer changes to Left Inferior Oblique.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the concept behind Park Three step test is crucial. Step-wise approach to such questions are necessary to solve them.

 

REF: KANSKI 8TH EDITION PAGE 826-827

choices.text: City university color vision test
Hardy Rand Rittler plates
American optical color plates test

questions.text: Identify the test given below:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pseudo isochromatic chart

 

Option A:

 

  • The given picture shows Ishihara’s pseudo isochromatic charts
  • Most commonly employed test.
  • Quick method of screening color blind individuals. It largely identifies red-green anomalies.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. City University Color Vision Test: This is another type of color vision test, but it is not the same as the Ishihara test.

 

Option C. Hardy, Rand, and Rittler (HRR) Plates: These are another set of pseudoisochromatic plates used for color vision testing, focusing on a wider range of color vision deficiencies, including blue-yellow deficiencies, but they are distinct from the Ishihara test.

 

Option D. American Optical/Hardy-Rand-Rittler (AO HRR) Test: This is a revised version of the HRR test, used for detecting both red-green and blue-yellow color vision deficiencies, and it is not the same as the Ishihara test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand that the Ishihara chart is a type of pseudoisochromatic plate test, specifically designed for detecting red-green color vision deficiencies.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology Khurana Page 326

choices.text: Constriction of blind spot  visual field

questions.text: A 37-year-old female came to the OPD with complaints of headache, nausea and decrease in vision. On examination, papilloedema is noted. All of the following statements are true regarding it, except?
questions.solution:
Ans.  D. Constriction of blind spot

 

Option D:

 

There is enlargement of blind spot seen in papilledema, no constriction. 
 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Transient Visual Obscurations: These are brief episodes of vision loss in patients with papilledema. They are typically triggered by changes in posture and are a common symptom, making this statement true.

 

Option B. This symptom is typically associated with disorders affecting the sixth cranial nerve (abducens nerve), leading to weakness of the lateral rectus muscle. In IIH, 6th nerve palsy can be seen as a false localizing sign thus causing horizonal gaze palsy. 

 

Option C. Blurring of Disc Margins: In papilledema, the optic disc swelling leads to blurring of the disc margins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the clinical features of papilledema. Papilledema typically presents with transient visual obscurations, blurring of disc margins, and an enlarged blind spot, may also be present with horizontal diplopia.

 

REF: COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY KHURANA PAGE 320

questions.text: This patient presented with bilateral ptosis. On application of ice, there was improvement in the ptosis. The likely diagnosis would be:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Myasthenia gravis

 

Option B:

 

  • Myasthenia gravis (MG) is an autoimmune disease in which antibodies mediate damage and destruction of acetylcholine receptors in striated muscle.
  • The test being done is ICE PACK TEST.
  • Improvement of ptosis on application of ice for 2 minutes is noted in MG as cold inhibits the breakdown of acetylcholine by acetylcholinesterase.
  • It is around 75% sensitive but highly specific.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Myotonic Dystrophy: This is a type of muscular dystrophy, characterized by progressive muscle wasting and weakness. It does not typically respond to the ice pack test.

 

Option C. Progressive External Ophthalmoplegia (PEO): This is a condition characterized by weakness of the eye muscles. While PEO shares some symptoms with myasthenia gravis, such as drooping eyelids and double vision, it does not respond to the ice pack test.

 

Option D. Millard-Gubler Syndrome: This is a rare condition characterized by facial paralysis, abducens nerve paralysis, and contralateral hemiplegia. It is not associated with a positive response to the ice pack test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ice pack test is most commonly used to diagnose myasthenia gravis, particularly when ocular symptoms like ptosis are present. It is not typically used or effective in diagnosing myotonic dystrophy, progressive external ophthalmoplegia, or Millard-Gubler syndrome.

 

REF: KANSKI 9TH EDITION page 815

choices.text: Increase in latency only
Increase in latency and decrease in amplitude
Decrease in latency and increase in amplitude

questions.text: VEP in optic neuropathy is?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increase in latency and decrease in amplitude

 

Option C:

 

  • Visual evoked potential (VEP) tests record electrical activity of the visual cortex created by retinal stimulation.
  • The most common indications in ophthalmology are the monitoring of visual function in babies and the investigation of optic neuropathy.
  • Interpretation - Latency and amplitude are assessed.
  • In optic neuropathy both parameters are affected, with prolongation of latency and decrease in amplitude.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Increase in Latency Only:

 

  • Latency refers to the time it takes for a signal to travel from the eye to the visual cortex in the brain.
  • An increase in latency means the signal is slower than normal, which can happen in optic neuropathy due to demyelination or other nerve damage.
  • However, this option does not consider changes in amplitude, which are also important in the context of optic nerve damage.

 

Option B. Increase in Amplitude Only:

 

  • Amplitude in VEP represents the strength or intensity of the signal reaching the visual cortex.
  • An increase in amplitude is not typically associated with optic neuropathy. In fact, optic nerve damage more commonly leads to a decrease in amplitude due to reduced signal transmission efficiency.

 

Option D. Decrease in Latency and Increase in Amplitude:

 

  • A decrease in latency would imply faster-than-normal signal transmission, which is not characteristic of optic neuropathy.
  • Similarly, an increase in amplitude is not typical of optic neuropathy, where signal strength usually diminishes.
  • This pattern is contrary to what is expected in optic nerve damage and is not a typical finding in optic neuropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize that in optic neuropathy, Visual Evoked Potentials typically show an increase in latency and a decrease in amplitude, reflecting delayed and weakened transmission of visual signals due to optic nerve damage.

 

REF: KANSKI 9TH EDITION PAGE 751

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the ophthalmologist with a complaint of blurring of vision since 15 days, noticed while driving. His visual acuity is to be tested using Snellen’s chart. The chart comprises of alphabets that are designed to fit in a square and subtend a particular angle at the nodal point of the patient’s eye. What is the angle subtended?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 5 minutes

 

Explanation:

 

Each letter of the snellen’s chart is so designed that it fits in a square, and subtends an angle of 5 minutes at the nodal point.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand that in the Snellen chart, the breadth of the optotype subtends a visual angle of 5 minute of arc at the patient's nodal point, which is a key aspect of its design for assessing visual acuity.

 

Ref: pg 266/ Anatomy and physiology of eye/ AK KHURANA/ 3rd edition

questions.text: The ability to obtain an impression of depth by the superimposition of 2 pictures of the same object is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stereopsis

 

Option A:

 

Stereopsis- ability to obtain an impression of depth by superimposition.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Fusion – ability of 2 eyes to produce composite pictures from 2 similar pictures.

 

 

Option C. Amblyopia- partial loss of sight in one or both eyes in the absence of ophthalmoscopic or objective signs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stereopsis refers to the ability to perceive depth by integrating the slightly different images from each eye, crucial for tasks that require depth perception.

 

Ref: pg 408/ Anatomy and physiology of eye/ AK KHURANA/ 3rd edition

questions.text: In Worth four dot test, the patient’s perception is shown in the image below.  What would be the interpretation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Orthophoria

 

Option C.

 

  • The test being done is Worth four-dot test – type of dissociation test.

  • Uses red-green goggles (red before right eye and green before left eye)

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Right Suppression: A person with suppression of the right eye will see only two green dots because the right eye (covered by the red lens) suppresses the red dot, and the white dot appears green through the green lens of the left eye.

 

Option B. Left Suppression: A person with suppression of the left eye will see three dots - two green and one red. The left eye (covered by the green lens) suppresses the green dots, and the white dot appears red through the red lens of the right eye.

 

Option D. Diplopia: If the person has double vision (diplopia), they will see five dots - three green (two from the right eye and one white dot seen as green by the left eye) and two red (one from the left eye and one white dot seen as red by the right eye).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Worth Four Dot Test results vary based on the patient's visual condition: right suppression shows two green dots, left suppression shows two green and one red dot, orthophoria shows two green, one red, and one combined dot, and diplopia shows three green and two red dots.

 

Ref: KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5TH EDITION PAGE 348

questions.text: When we fix our visual attention on an object of regard, the image is formed on the fovea of both our eyes separately; but we perceive a single image. Which of the following is not a component of this state of binocular single vision?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fixation

 

Option C:

 

Fixation is the ability to maintain visual gaze on a single location.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fusion:

 

Fusion is a key component of binocular single vision. It is the process by which the brain combines the two slightly different images received from each eye into a single, unified image. This is crucial for achieving binocular single vision.

 

Option B. Simultaneous Perception:

 

Simultaneous perception is also an essential component of binocular single vision. It refers to the ability of the visual system to perceive images presented to each eye simultaneously, which is a prerequisite for fusion to occur.

 

Option D. Stereopsis:

 

Stereopsis is the perception of depth that arises from the brain's processing of the slightly different images from each eye. It is a higher-level outcome of binocular single vision, but not a fundamental component of achieving binocular single vision itself. Stereopsis is dependent on the successful integration of the other components (fusion and simultaneous perception).

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the context of binocular single vision, fixation is not a component specific to this state.

 

Ref: KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5TH EDITION pg.no 339

questions.text: A patient presented with deviation of right eye in primary gaze. On testing, the corneal reflex was noted to be at the nasal limbus. The deviation in prism diopter is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 90∆ exotropia

 

Option B:

 

  • Tropias (manifest squint) are examined by Hirschberg corneal reflex test.
  • It is performed by shining the light on person’s eye.

 

 

  • The distance between the normal and abnormal reflection is measured and the calculation is done as follows:
    • Every 1 mm = 7 degree squint.
    • 1 degree = 2 prism dioptre.

 

The angle of squint is 15 degree and 45 degree when the corneal light reflex falls on the           border of pupil and limbus respectively.

 

  • In this question, the reflection of light is at the nasal (inner) limbus of the right eye, which means it is 45 degree or 90∆ exotropia.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. 45∆ esotropia – Indicates that the Hirschberg reflex should lie between pupil and limbus.

 

Option C. 30∆ esotropia – Indicates that the Hirschberg reflex should lie at the pupillary border.

 

Option D. 60∆ exotropia - Indicates that the Hirschberg reflex should lie between pupil and limbus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The reflection of light is at the nasal (inner) limbus of the right eye, which means it is 45 degree or 90∆ exotropia.

 

Ref: KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5TH EDITION pg.no 347

questions.text: Based on the test finding given below, what would the diagnosis be?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Esophoria

 

Option A:

 

  • The conclusion from the test is: Esophoria.
  • The given test is MADDOX ROD TEST.
  • This is done in a suspected case of heterophoria.
  • A Maddox rod consists of four or five cylinders of red glass side by side in a supporting disc and is placed in the trial frame before one eye.
  • Interpretation is as follows:

 

Esophoria:

 

  • Findings: In esophoria, the eyes tend to converge more than required when focusing on an object. When the Maddox Rod is placed in front of right eye, the patient with esophoria will see two images: a point light (seen by the uncovered eye) and a line (seen through the Maddox Rod). The line will appear to the left of the light.
  • Interpretation: The displacement of the line to the left indicates a tendency for the covered eye to turn inward, characteristic of esophoria.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Orthophoria:

 

Findings: In orthophoria, the eyes are properly aligned with each other. When using the Maddox Rod, the patient will see the point light and the line in alignment with each other.

 

Interpretation: The alignment of the line with the light indicates that there is no latent deviation of the eyes, and the ocular alignment is normal.

 

Option C. Exophoria:

 

Findings: In exophoria, the eyes tend to diverge away from each other. When the Maddox Rod is placed in front of right eye, the patient with exophoria will see the line displaced to the right of the point light

 

Interpretation: The displacement of the line to the right indicates a tendency for the covered eye to turn outward, characteristic of exophoria.

 

Option D. Hypophoria:

 

Findings: In hypophoria, there is a tendency for one eye to drift downward. When the Maddox Rod is placed horizontally in front of one eye, the patient with hypophoria will see the line displaced either above or below the light, depending on which eye is covered and the direction of the deviation.

 

Interpretation: The vertical displacement of the line indicates a tendency for the covered eye to deviate downward, characteristic of hypophoria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the Maddox rod test, the point source of light is seen by the uncovered eye, while the covered eye sees the line. In esotropia, the line is displaced to left of the dot, when right eye is covered and vice-versa when left eye is covered.

 

Ref: PARSON’S DISEASES OF EYE PG.NO: 423

questions.text: Based on the evaluation of a patient with strabismus, a 15º primary deviation and 30º secondary deviation were recorded. What type of strabismus does this indicate?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Paralytic squint

 

Option C:

 

 

  • In case of paralytic squint – secondary deviation > primary deviation.
  • This is based on HERING’S LAW OF EQUAL INNERVATION OF YOKE MUSCLES.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Concomitant Squint:

 

In concomitant squint (also known as non-paralytic or comitant squint), the degree of deviation remains constant regardless of the direction of gaze. It means that the angle of misalignment does not change when the patient looks in different directions.

 

Primary deviation = Secondary deviation.

 

Option B. Accommodative Esotropia:

 

Accommodative esotropia is a type of concomitant squint where the eyes turn inward. It is often related to uncorrected hyperopia and the eye's effort to accommodate leads to convergence and thus inward turning of the eyes. Like other forms of concomitant squint, the primary and secondary deviations in accommodative esotropia are equal.

 

Option D. Convergence Insufficiency:

 

Convergence insufficiency is a condition where the eyes do not work together well while focusing on a near object. The eyes have difficulty converging adequately for near work, leading to symptoms like eyestrain and blurring - asthenopia. It does not typically present with a difference between primary and secondary deviations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 In a case with a 15º primary deviation and a 30º secondary deviation in strabismus, the diagnosis is indicative of a paralytic squint. This finding is characteristic of paralytic strabismus, where the secondary deviation (when the affected eye is fixating) is greater than the primary deviation (when the unaffected eye is fixating), reflecting the impact of muscle weakness or paralysis.

 

Ref: KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5TH EDITION pg.no 351

questions.text: Identify the condition:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Brown syndrome

 

Option B:

 

  • This picture shows defect in elevation of right eye in adducted position – suggestive of BROWN’S SUPERIOR OBLIQUE TENDON SHEATH SYNDROME.
  • Inability to elevate an adducted eye can be due to:
    • Inferior oblique paresis (rare)
    • Superior oblique muscle causing mechanical restriction

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Möbius syndrome: Characterized by congenital facial paralysis and abducens nerve palsy, leading to limited facial expression and lateral gaze palsy.

 

 

Option C. Marcus Gunn syndrome (Marcus Gunn Jaw-Winking Phenomenon): Involves an abnormal connection between the muscles of jaw movement and the eyelid, causing the upper eyelid to elevate involuntarily during jaw movement.

 

 

Option D. Duane’s syndrome: Marked by limited horizontal eye movement, often with retraction of the eyeball into the socket and narrowing of the eyelid opening when trying to look inward or outward.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brown syndrome presents with inability to elevate the affected eye in adduction due to a restriction in the superior oblique tendon.

 

Ref: KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5TH EDITION pg.no 355

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient came with complaint of inability to look up following a hit to the eye with a tennis ball. On examination, the forced duction test is positive. What is the muscle abnormality in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inferior rectus entrapment

 

Option C:

 

 

  • The given scenario suggests entrapment of inferior rectus muscle - form of restrictive squint.
  • Smaller deviation in primary position in proportion to limitation of ocular movement.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Superior rectus entrapment: This muscle is responsible for upward gaze, but entrapment is less likely because it is not commonly entrapped following orbital trauma.

 

Option B. Superior rectus palsy: Palsy would imply a nerve dysfunction, which is less likely given the positive forced duction test indicating a mechanical restriction.

 

Option D. Inferior rectus palsy: Similar to superior rectus palsy, this would suggest nerve dysfunction, not a mechanical restriction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The likely muscle abnormality in a patient with trauma to the eye, inability to look up, and a positive forced duction test is entrapment of the inferior rectus muscle.

 

Ref: KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5TH EDITION pg.no 355

choices.text: Small angle of squint
Onset is within 2 years of age
Cross fixation in side gaze noted
Presence of significant refractive error

questions.text: A 5-month-old infant with cerebral palsy is brought in by her mother due to a recent onset of eye deviation. The mother reports that the deviation is more noticeable when the child is focusing on objects. The child has no history of trauma, infection, and is up-to-date with vaccinations. During the physical examination, you note that the child's eyes do not align properly, especially in lateral gaze. Based on this presentation, which of the following is the most likely characteristic of this child's strabismus?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cross fixation in side gaze noted

 

Option C:

 

  • The given scenario is suggestive of EARLY-ONSET ESOTROPIA.
  • Idiopathic condition.
  • Develops within 6 months of life.
  • Features include
  • Large angle squint
  • Alternate fixation in primary gaze and cross fixation in side gaze
  • No significant refractive error

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Small Angle of Squint: Early onset esotropia often presents with a large angle of squint rather than a small one.

 

Option B. Onset is Within 2 Years of Age: Early onset esotropia, as the name suggests, typically begins in infancy or early childhood. The most common form, congenital or infantile esotropia, often appears before the child reaches 6 months of age.

 

Option D. Presence of Significant Refractive Error: While refractive errors can be associated with some forms of strabismus, early onset esotropia is not typically characterized by significant refractive errors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize that early onset esotropia typically presents within the first two years of life, often with large-angle squint and cross fixation behavior, but not necessarily with significant refractive errors.

 

Ref: KANSKI 9TH EDITION pg.no: 728

choices.text: Recession of right lateral rectus and medial rectus
Resection of right lateral rectus and medial rectus
Resection of right lateral rectus and recession of right medial rectus
Recession of right lateral rectus and resection of right medial rectus

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient came to the OPD with a complaint of double vision since few months which was worse for distant objects. The patient gave a history of deviation of one eye since childhood. On examination,right esotropia was noted and after further evaluation, a diagnosis of right lateral rectus palsy was made. What is the ideal surgical procedure for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Resection of right lateral rectus and recession of right medial rectus

 

Option C:

 

  • In case of paralytic squint, surgical treatment is done if recovery doesn’t occur in 6 months.
  • PRINCIPLES OF SURGICAL CORRECTION
    • Strengthen the paralysed muscle by resection.
    • Weaken the overacting muscle by recession.
    • In advanced cases, transplantation of normal muscle tendon adjacent to paralysed muscle tendon.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Recession of right lateral rectus and medial rectus: This would not be ideal for lateral rectus palsy. Recession (weakening) of the already palsied lateral rectus would exacerbate the problem, and recessing the medial rectus of the same eye could lead to significant imbalance.

 

Option B. Resection of right lateral rectus and medial rectus: Resecting (shortening/strengthening) the palsied lateral rectus might be considered, but resecting the medial rectus in the same eye typically would not be indicated as it would further imbalance the eye.

 

Option D. Recession of right lateral rectus and resection of right medial rectus: Recession (weakening) of a palsied muscle and resection (strengthening) of its antagonist will worsen the squint and the diplopia in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with right lateral rectus palsy, the ideal surgical intervention typically involves resecting (strengthening) the weak right lateral rectus and recessing (weakening) the opposing right medial rectus to restore ocular balance and alignment.

 

Ref: KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5TH EDITION pg.no: 354

questions.text: Which of the following types of amblyopia is associated with worst prognosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Stimulus deprivation amblyopia

 

Option C:

 

  • The least common, most severe and difficult to treat, is visual deprivation amblyopia (also known as stimulus deprivation amblyopia).
  • This is due to an eye abnormality that obstructs the visual axis or otherwise interferes with central vision.

 

CAUSES:

 

  1. Congenital or early-acquired cataract
  2. Blepharoptosis
  3. Periocular lesions obstructing the visual axis
  4. Corneal opacities
  5. Vitreous haemorrhage

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Anisometropic Amblyopia: This results from unequal refractive errors in the two eyes. Its prognosis is generally good with appropriate corrective lenses and amblyopia therapy, especially if treated early.

 

Option B. Strabismic Amblyopia: Caused by misalignment of the eyes (strabismus), this type of amblyopia has a variable prognosis depending on the severity and treatment of the strabismus.

 

Option D. Meridional Amblyopia: Associated with uncorrected astigmatism, this type of amblyopia has a generally good prognosis with appropriate corrective lenses and amblyopia therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stimulus deprivation amblyopia has the worst prognosis among the types of amblyopia listed, due to the profound impact of visual deprivation during the critical developmental period of the visual system.

 

Ref: AAO PAEDIATRIC OPHTHALMOLOGY AND STRABISMUS PAGE 55

questions.text: Which is the thickest wall of the orbit?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lateral wall

 

Option B:

 

  • Lateral orbital wall is made up of- zygomatic bone, greater wing of sphenoid.

  • It is the thickest & strongest orbital wall.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Medial Wall: The medial wall of the orbit is one of the thinnest and most fragile parts. It is formed primarily by the ethmoid bone and partly by the lacrimal bone, the frontal bone, and the lesser wing of the sphenoid. This wall separates the orbital cavity from the ethmoid air cells, making it prone to injury and subsequent communication with the nasal cavity.

 

 

Option C. Roof: The roof of the orbit is formed primarily by the orbital plate of the frontal bone and, to a lesser extent, by the lesser wing of the sphenoid. It separates the orbital contents from the anterior cranial fossa and provides protection from superior impacts. It's relatively thin compared to the lateral wall but stronger than the medial wall.

 

 

Option D. Floor: The floor of the orbit is formed by the orbital surface of the maxillary bone, along with small contributions from the zygomatic bone and the palatine bone. This wall is thin and vulnerable to fractures, especially from trauma to the orbit, as it separates the orbital contents from the maxillary sinus.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lateral wall is the thickest wall of the orbit, providing substantial protection to the eye from lateral impacts, and distinguishing itself in strength and thickness from the more fragile medial wall, the moderately strong roof, and the thin, vulnerable floor of the orbit.

 

Ref: pg 578/ anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a two-day history of severe headache, fever, and double vision. She recently had a dental abscess treated. On examination, she has a temperature of 38.5°C, and her visual examination shows impaired lateral movement of the right eye. There is no ptosis or pupillary abnormality. Her facial sensation is intact. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain shows evidence suggestive of cavernous sinus thrombosis.

 

 

Which cranial nerve is most likely involved first in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Abducent

 

Option C:

 

Cavernous sinus thrombosis causes painful ophthalmoplegia involving the following cranial nerves:

 

  • III (Oculomotor)

  • IV (Trochlear)

  • VI (Abducent) (1st to be involved as it passes through the sinus)

  • V (I) (Ophthalmic branch of Trigeminal nerve)

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Oculomotor (Cranial Nerve III): This nerve controls most of the eye's movements, the constriction of the pupil, and maintains an open eyelid. In cavernous sinus thrombosis, its involvement typically results in ptosis (drooping eyelid), pupillary dilation, and limited eye movement except for lateral and downward gaze.

 

Option B. Trochlear (Cranial Nerve IV): This nerve innervates the superior oblique muscle, which is responsible for downward and lateral eye movement. Its involvement would lead to vertical diplopia, particularly when looking down.

 

Option D. Trigeminal (Cranial Nerve V): This nerve is responsible for facial sensation and motor functions of the muscles of mastication. Involvement in cavernous sinus thrombosis would cause facial sensory loss and chewing difficulties but not eye movement disorders.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cavernous sinus thrombosis, the abducent nerve (Cranial Nerve VI) is typically the earliest to be affected due to its vulnerability within the cavernous sinus, often presenting with an inability to abduct the eye and resulting in horizontal diplopia.

 

Ref: pg 412,6th edition, comprehensive ophthalmology ak khurana

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the clinic by his parents who are concerned about his unusual eyelid movement. They report that every time he suckles while breastfeeding, his right upper eyelid retracts unusually. There is no history of trauma or surgery. On examination, you notice that the right upper eyelid droops slightly in a neutral facial expression and elevates when the infant is smiling or crying. This condition is likely due to an aberrant connection between the muscles innervated by which two cranial nerves?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3 & 5

 

Option C:

 

  • Other names of Marcus-Gunn aJaw Winking Syndrome include Marcus-Gunn jaw winking phenomenon (MGP), Marcus Gunn ptosis, Marcus Gunn jaw winking trigemino-oculomotor synkinesis, Maxillopalpebral synkinesis, and Pterygoid-levator synkinesis.
  • These individuals have variable degrees of blepharoptosis in the resting, primary position.
  • It is one of the congenital cranial dysinnervation disorders.
  • It is associated with synkinetic movements of the upper eyelid during masticating movements of the jaw. It is usually unilateral but may present bilaterally also.
  • There occurs a coordinated synkinetic movement of the upper eyelid and the jaw as a result of an abnormal connection between the motor branches of the trigeminal nerve and superior division of oculomotor nerve.
  • The jaw-wink reflex consists of a momentary retraction/elevation of the upper eyelid (which was ptotic) upon stimulation of the ipsilateral pterygoid muscle, which is followed by a rapid return to a lower position.
  • The magnitude of the wink is worse in downgaze.
  • This synkinetic phenomenon may be elicited not only by opening the mouth, but also by thrusting the jaw to the contralateral side, jaw protrusion, chewing, smiling, or sucking.
  • Congenital synkinetic ptosis is also known as Marcus gunn jaw winking syndrome.
  • Synkinesis is when two or more muscles that are independently innervated have either simultaneous or coordinated movements.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. 3 & 7: This option suggests a connection between the oculomotor nerve (CN III), which innervates the levator palpebrae superioris (responsible for eyelid elevation), and the facial nerve (CN VII), which controls facial expressions.

 

Option B.  4 & 5: The trochlear nerve (CN IV) innervates the superior oblique muscle of the eye, and the trigeminal nerve (CN V) is responsible for facial sensation and mastication. An aberrant connection here is unlikely to cause the described eyelid phenomenon.

 

Option D. 5 & 7: This option suggests a connection between the trigeminal nerve (CN V) and the facial nerve (CN VII). While the facial nerve is involved in facial expressions, the trigeminal nerve's role in sensation and mastication does not typically lead to eyelid synkinesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For medical students preparing for residency, it's essential to understand that congenital synkinetic ptosis typically results from an aberrant innervation between the oculomotor nerve (CN III) and the motor division of Trigeminal nerve (CN V), leading to an unusual elevation of the eyelid during facial movements like smiling or crying.

 

Ref: pg 41, eyelids -kanski’s clinical ophthalmology 8th edition.

2. Demirci H, Frueh BR, Nelson CC. Marcus Gunn jaw-winking synkinesis: clinical features and management. Ophthalmology. 2010 Jul;117(7):1447-52. doi: 10.1016/j.ophtha.2009.11.014. Epub 2010 Feb 25. PMID: 20188419.

choices.text: Infraorbital nerve anesthesia

questions.text: Which of the following is not a sign of a blow-out fracture of orbit?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Exophthalmos

 

Option A:

 

A blow out fracture of the orbital floor is caused by sudden increase in orbital pressure due to trauma.

 

Signs:

 

  • Enophthalmos - due to displacement of intraorbital contents
  • Diplopia – due to extra ocular muscle entrapment in fracture
  • Infra orbital anesthesia - if fracture involves infra orbital canal through which infra orbital nerve passes.
  • Others - periorbital edema, ecchymosis, subcutaneous emphysema, etc

 

PlainX-Ray- Water’s view is the best.

 

Most common wall of the orbit to be fractured in blow-out fractures is the floor.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Diplopia: It is a common symptom of blow-out fractures, often resulting from impaired movement of the affected eye due to muscle entrapment or nerve damage.

 

Option C. Enophthalmos: This is the posterior displacement of the eye within the orbit, leading to a sunken appearance. It is a characteristic sign of blow-out fractures. The increase in the orbital volume caused by the fracture allows the eyeball to sink backward.

 

Option D. Infraorbital nerve anesthesia: This refers to a loss of sensation in the area supplied by the infraorbital nerve, typically the lower eyelid, cheek, and upper lip. It can occur in blow-out fractures if the fracture involves the infraorbital groove or canal, where the nerve runs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enophthalmos, not exophthalmos, is a sign of blow-out fracture of the orbit. Blow-out fractures typically increase orbital volume, allowing the eyeball to sink backward, leading to enophthalmos, rather than protruding forward as in exophthalmos.

 

Ref: pg 864 kanski’s clinical ophthalmology 8th edition

questions.text: A 59-year-old male patient came with the complaint of shortness of breath. On examination, fullness in the right supraclavicular region is observed. On ocular examination, right pupil is constricted. Which of the following is not a feature of the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Heterochromia Iridis

 

Option C:

 

This condition, characterized by a difference in color between the two irises, is not typically a feature of adult-onset Horner's syndrome. It is more commonly associated with congenital Horner's syndrome, where the condition is present from birth or early childhood.

 

Causes of HORNER’S SYNDROME:

 

  • Ptosis

  • Miosis

  • Heterochromia iridis

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ptosis: This is a hallmark feature of Horner's syndrome. It occurs due to paralysis of the Müller's muscle, a sympathetically innervated muscle in the eyelid, leading to a slight drooping of the upper eyelid.

 

Option B. Anhidrosis: This refers to the absence or decrease in sweating on the affected side of the face. It is a feature of Horner's syndrome due to the disruption of sympathetic nerves that innervate sweat glands.

 

Option D. Enophthalmos: This refers to the posterior displacement of the eyeball within the orbit, leading to a sunken appearance. While mild enophthalmos can be associated with Horner's syndrome due to the lack of sympathetic tone to the orbitalis muscle, it is not as prominent or diagnostic as the other features.

 

Conclusion:

 

Heterochromia iridis is not a typical feature of adult onset Horner's syndrome. The classic triad of Horner's syndrome consists of ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis, with enophthalmos being a less prominent associated feature.

 

Ref: pg344/anatomy & physiology of eye 3rd edition – ak Khurana (pg 575)

questions.text: A patient present with proptosis, vision changes, and eye pain. After thorough examination and imaging, the ophthalmologist makes the diagnosis of an orbital tumour. Which is the most common benign orbital tumour in adults?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cavernous haemangioma

 

Option B:

 

Cavernous hemangiomas are the most common primary benign orbital tumors in adults. They are slow-growing vascular lesions that can cause proptosis and visual changes due to their size and location.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Rhabdomyosarcoma: This is a type of malignant tumor that arises from skeletal muscle. It is the most common primary orbital malignancy in children, not adults.

 

Option C. Non-Hodgkin’s Lymphoma: This represents a group of blood cancers that develop in the lymphatic system. While it can involve the orbit, it is not classified as a benign tumor. Orbital involvement in non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma usually indicates a systemic disease rather than a primary orbital tumor.

 

Option D. Neuroblastoma: This is a malignant tumor that arises from nerve tissue. It is most commonly seen in children and is not a benign tumor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common benign orbital tumor in adults is a cavernous hemangioma.

 

Ref: pg 102/orbit/kanski’s clinical ophthalmology 8th edition.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy was brought to the pediatric emergency with complaints of 5 days of progressive left facial swelling and fever. On ocular inspection, left periorbital oedema, erythema and discharge are noted. On examination, left eye showed decrease in visual acuity, and the pupil showed relative afferent pupillary defect. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Orbital cellulitis

 

Option B:

 

Orbital cellulitis-

 

  • Fever, chills

  • Periorbital edema, erythema, extra ocular movement restriction

  • Optic nerve involvement- decreased vision, RAPD

  • If progresses- intra orbital abscess.

 

Other choices: Usually don’t present with fever, chills, erythema.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. AV Malformation (Arteriovenous Malformation): This is an abnormal connection between arteries and veins, bypassing the capillary system. It can cause swelling and other issues due to altered blood flow, but it typically does not present with infection-like symptoms (fever, discharge) or a rapid onset of visual changes and RAPD.

 

Option C. Retinoblastoma: A malignant tumor of the retina, common in children. It usually presents with a white pupillary reflex (leukocoria) and may cause vision loss. However, retinoblastoma does not typically cause fever, periorbital edema, or erythema, which are indicative of an infectious process.

 

Option D. Neuroblastoma: A cancer that develops from immature nerve cells, mostly occurring in children. It can present with various symptoms depending on the site of the tumor but is unlikely to cause localized periorbital edema, erythema, and discharge without other systemic or neurological symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a pediatric patient presenting with fever, progressive facial swelling, periorbital edema, erythema, discharge, decreased visual acuity, and RAPD, the most probable diagnosis is Orbital Cellulitis, an infectious condition characterized by inflammation and infection of the orbital tissues, often requiring prompt medical intervention.

 

Ref: pg 409/ orbit/ 6th edition comprehensive ophthalmology  ak khurana

choices.text: Ice pack test
Snap back test

questions.text: In a 35-year-old woman with a history of right eye ptosis for 6 months, the eyelids appear asymmetrical, and the ptosis fluctuates throughout the day, worsening in the evening. The fatigability test shows positive results. Which of the following tests is not helpful in diagnosing the condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Snap back test

 

Option C:

 

Snap back test is used for ectropion, to check lower lid laxity.

 

The following signs and symptoms given in the question are suggestive of Myasthenic ptosis:

 

  • Unilateral
  • Asymmetrical
  • Diurnal variation
  • Fatigability present

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Edrophonium Test: This test is useful in diagnosing MG. Edrophonium, a short-acting acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, temporarily increases the availability of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, leading to an improvement in muscle strength in patients with MG.

 

Option B. Ice Pack Test: This test is also helpful in MG. Cooling improves neuromuscular transmission, and thus, application of an ice pack on the eyelids can temporarily improve ptosis in MG.

 

Option D. Electromyography (EMG): EMG, especially single-fiber EMG, is a key diagnostic tool in MG. It measures the electrical activity of muscles and can detect the characteristic patterns of neuromuscular transmission failure seen in MG.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the evaluation of a patient with fluctuating ptosis and positive fatigability, suggesting Myasthenia Gravis, the Snap Back Test is not useful as it assesses eyelid laxity rather than neuromuscular strength or transmission, which are the key pathological features in Myasthenia Gravis.

 

Ref: pg 838/ neuro ophthalmology/ kanski’s clinical ophthalmology 8th edition

questions.text: Which is the smallest diameter of an eyeball?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vertical

 

Option B:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Horizontal: The horizontal diameter, also known as the equatorial diameter, typically measures about 24 mm. This is the widest diameter of the eye.

 

Option C. Anteroposterior: The anteroposterior diameter, or axial length, of the eye is the distance from the front (cornea) to the back (retina) of the eye. This measures approximately 22 to 24 mm in adults, making it similar or slightly less than the horizontal diameter.

 

Option D. Transverse: The term "transverse diameter" is less commonly used in reference to eye anatomy and generally considered synonymous with the horizontal diameter.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The smallest diameter of an eyeball is the vertical diameter.

 

Ref: pg 2/ anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

choices.text: Von graefe’s sign

questions.text: Identify the sign:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Von graefe’s sign

 

Option B:

 

It refers to the delayed movement of the upper eyelid when the eye moves downward, creating a noticeable rim of sclera above the iris.

 

  1. Stellwag sign- incomplete and frequent blinking
  2. Gifford sign- difficulty while everting the upper eyelid
  3. Jellinek sign- abnormal pigmentation of upper eyelid
  4. Enroth sign- lower eyelid edema
  5. Griffith sign- lid lag on upgaze
  6. Mobius sign- not able to converge eyes
  7. Ballet's sign- one or more extraocular muscle restriction
  8. Von graefe sign- retarded descent of upper lid in downgaze
  9. Joffrey sign- absent crease of the forehead in superior gaze
  10. Kocher's sign- staring and frightened appearance of eyes
  11. Dalyrymple sign- eyelid retraction

 

Mnemonic: The signs in Graves’ disease can be remembered as

 

G — Gifford’s sign

 

R — Rosenbach’s sign

 

A — Absent convergence (Mobius sign)

 

V — Von Graefe’s sign

 

E — Enroth’s sign

 

S — Stellwag’s sign

 

 

Disease — Dalrymple’s sign

 

  • Rosenbach’s sign: Reads like watching Rosy, that will result in tremors.
  • Mobius: Muscle problem (Mostly inferior rectus)
  • Von Graefe’s: Reads like Giraffe. On watching a Giraffe, obviously lid will take time to come down (lid lag)
  • Enroth: Edema of eyelid
  • Stellwag: Staring look (means no blinking)
  • DALRymple: DAlrymples has Lid Retraction
  • GIfford: Gone Inside (When eyelid has gone inside, it will be difficult to be everted)

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Dalrymple's Sign: This is characterized by an abnormal widening of the palpebral fissure due to retraction of the upper eyelid, giving the appearance of a stare.

 

 

Option C. Stellwag's Sign: This sign is marked by a reduced frequency or absence of blinking, contributing to the characteristic stare of Graves' disease.

 

Option D. Sign: It indicates an inability or weakness in maintaining convergence of the eyes, often observed during prolonged focusing on a near object.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The delayed movement of the upper eyelid when the eye moves downward, creating a noticeable rim of sclera above the iris is Von Graffe’s sign.

 

Ref: American association of ophthalmologyhttps://eyewiki.aao.org/thyroid_eye_disease

choices.text: Downwards, backwards and medially
Upwards, inwards and backwards
Downwards, outwards and forwards
Downwards, backwards and laterally

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant presents with persistent tearing, recurrent eye infections, and crusting around the left eye since birth. The pediatrician suspects nasolacrimal duct obstruction and suggests Crigler’s massage and prescribes antibiotics. In which direction is the involved duct directed?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Downwards, backwards and laterally

 

Explanation:

 

The NLD runs in a bony canal formed by maxilla and inferior turbinate directed downwards, backwards and laterally.

 

Students should read the question carefully. The direction of the NLD is not to be confused with the direction of the canaliculus which is directed medially.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

 The nasolacrimal duct is directed downwards, backwards and laterally.

 

Ref: pg 459/ / Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

choices.text: Tear film break up time
None of the above

questions.text: Identify the test:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Jones test

 

Option C:

 

JONES - to check the patency of lacrimal drainage pathway with fluorescein.

 

The given image is of a positive primary Jones dye test.

 

  • The primary test: differentiates partial obstruction of the lacrimal passages and lacrimal pump failure from primary hypersecretion of tears.
  • The secondary (irrigation) test: Identifies lacrimal pump failure or the probable site of partial obstruction, on the basis of whether the topical fluorescein instilled for the primary test entered the lacrimal sac.

 

 

 

Fig: Jones dye testing. A. primary B. Secondary

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Schirmer test: Measures total tear secretion. A value <10mm is suggestive of dry eye.

 

 

Option B. Tear film break up time: Indicator of adequacy of mucin component of tear film. Less than 10 seconds indicates unstable tear film. The image below shows multiple dry spots in a fluorescein-stained tear film.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Jones test is the test to assess the patency of the lacrimal pathway using fluorescein dye.

 

Ref: Patel J, Levin A, Patel BC. Epiphora Clinical Testing. [Updated 2023 Jul 25]. In: Stat Pearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): Stat Pearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557424/

choices.text: At the junction of lacrimal sac and NLD
In the middle part of NLD
At the opening of NLD in the inferior meatus
Between the common canaliculus and lacrimal sac

questions.text: The most common cause of congenital lacrimal sac obstruction is due to imperforate Valve of Hasner. Where is this valve located?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) At the opening of NLD in the inferior meatus

 

Option C:

 

  • The lumen of the nasolacrimal duct is marked by numerous folds of mucous membrane, known as the valves.
  • Valve of Hasner is situated in the lower end of NLD at the inferior meatus.
  • It prevents the entry of the air into the lacrimal sac, when air is blown out of a closed nose.

 

Explanation:

 

Option D - Between Common Canaliculus and Lacrimal Sac: This is the location of the Valve of Rosenmuller.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The valve of Hasner is located at the opening of NLD in inferior meatus.

 

 

Ref: pg 460 / Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

choices.text: Gland of Moll
Gland of Zeis
Gland of Krausse

questions.text: Identify the gland marked with a red arrow:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Meibomian gland

 

Option A:

 

  • They are modified sweat glands.
  • Embedded on tarsal plates, hence also known as Tarsal glands.
  • Openings are arranged in a single row on the lid margin between grey line & posterior border.
  • Secrete outermost lipid layer of tear film.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Gland of Moll: These are apocrine sweat glands found in the eyelids. They are different from the tarsal (Meibomian) glands and are associated with the hair follicles of the eyelashes.

 

Option C. Gland of Zeis: These are small sebaceous glands associated with the eyelashes and are not the same as the tarsal glands. They secrete a substance that lubricates the eyelashes.

 

Option D. Gland of Krausse: These are minor glands in the eyelid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The tarsal glands are the same as the Meibomian glands, which are sebaceous glands within the eyelids contributing to the tear film.

 

Ref: pg 497/ Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

choices.text: Squamous cell carcinoma
Basal cell carcinoma
Sebaceous cell carcinoma

questions.text: A 62-year-old male patient comes to the OPD with complaints of a swelling on the eyelid. He gives history of a similar complaint multiple times in the past. The ophthalmologist diagnoses it as a case of recurrent chalazion and sends it for histopathological examination. What is the ophthalmologist excluding the probability of?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sebaceous cell carcinoma

 

Option D:

 

  • Chalazion is a chronic non-infective lipogranulomatous inflammation of the meibomian gland.
  • It is a painless swelling in the eyelid away from lid margin with heaviness.
  • Complications:
    • Hordeolum internum (due to secondary infection)
    • Malignant change into adenocarcinoma or sebaceous cell carcinoma in elderly patients
  • Blurred vision
  • Large chalazion may induce astigmatism

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Squamous Cell Carcinoma: This is a type of skin cancer that can occur on the eyelids, often resulting from prolonged exposure to ultraviolet (UV) light. While it can present as a lesion on the eyelid, its clinical appearance is usually different from that of a chalazion, typically showing more superficial, scaly, and ulcerative features.

 

 

Option B. Basal Cell Carcinoma: The most common type of eyelid cancer, basal cell carcinoma often presents as a painless, slowly growing nodule on the eyelid with potential ulceration or a pearly appearance.

 

 

Option C. Malignant Melanoma: This is a type of cancer that develops from the pigment-containing cells known as melanocytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The histopathological examination of a recurrent chalazion is primarily conducted to exclude the possibility of sebaceous cell carcinoma.

 

Ref: pg 369 – eyelids- 6th edition – comprehensive ophthalmology ak khurana

questions.text: A 55-year-old male, presented to the OPD with grade 3 ectropion more pronounced on the lateral half of the left lower lid. Identify the surgical procedure of choice:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Modified Kuhnt Szymanowski

 

Option A:

 

Byron Smith's modified Kuhnt-Szymanowski operation treats severe ectropion by using a pentagonal eyelid excision and triangular skin excision near the lateral canthus for lid elevation.

 

 It is a procedure for Ectropion correction, which combines a blepharoplasty-type lower lid incision with a wedge resection of the lateral part of the posterior lamella of the lower eyelid.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Lateral Tarsal Stripping: This procedure is used to correct lower eyelid laxity and malposition. It involves the surgical tightening of the lateral lower eyelid by excising a strip of the lateral tarsal conjunctiva and lower eyelid retractors. It helps to reposition and stabilize the lower eyelid, often used in cases of entropion or ectropion.

 

 

Option C. Wies Procedure: The Wies procedure is a surgical technique used to correct minor-to-moderate entropion, particularly when it involves the lower eyelid. It involves a horizontal tightening of the eyelid margin without shortening the horizontal length of the eyelid. A small section of the outer eyelid is removed, and then the eyelid is sutured to tighten and reposition it, which helps in turning the eyelid margin outward, correcting the entropion.

 

 

Option D. Z-Plasty: Z-plasty is a surgical technique used to revise scars, but it's also employed in eyelid surgeries for conditions like ectropion. It involves creating two triangular flaps of equal dimension that are transposed to reorient and lengthen the scar or contracted tissue. In eyelid surgery, this technique can be used to redistribute tissue, correct cicatricial ectropion, or address eyelid deformities that result from scarring.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with Grade 3 Ectropion with lateral lid laxity, Kuhnt-Szymanowski procedure is the treatment of choice.

 

Ref: pg 376/ eye lids/6th edition/ comprehensive ophthalmology ak khurana

questions.text: What surgical procedure involves the plication of lower lid retractors to correct entropion?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Jones procedure

 

Option B:

 

The principle of Jones procedure and Weis procedure is to prevent override of orbicularis muscle.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Weis Procedure: The Weiss procedure, is designed to correct entropion, specifically of the lower eyelid. It involves a horizontal tightening of the eyelid margin, usually without shortening the horizontal length of the eyelid. A small section of the outer eyelid is removed and then sutured to reposition and tighten the eyelid, thereby correcting the inward turning of the eyelid.

 

 

Option C. Quickert’s Procedure: Quickert’s procedure is a surgical technique specifically designed to correct involutional entropion.

 

Quickert sutures tighten lower lid retractors. Accordingly, the safety, simplicity, quickness, and overall patient satisfaction have been cited as reasons to consider the Quickert procedure for patients in whom these features would be valuable, or patients with higher operative risk

 

 

Option D. Modified Wheeler Operation: The Modified Wheeler Operation is another surgical technique for correcting lower eyelid entropion. It involves resecting a part of the tarsal plate along with the adjacent conjunctiva and then suturing the edges. This technique is often used when there's a need to shorten the horizontal length of the eyelid due to laxity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Jones procedure is plication of lower lid retractors to correct entropion.

 

Ref: 373/eye lids/6th edition/ comprehensive ophthalmology ak khurana

questions.text: Name the condition:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ankyloblepharon

 

Option B:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Symblepharon

 

 

Option C.  Euryblepharon

 

 

Option D.  Blepharophimosis
