Ankyloblepharon is an adhesion between upper & lower lid margin.

 

Ref: pg 62/eyelids/kanski’s clinical ophthalmology 8th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the given clinical syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Exotropia

 

Option B:

 

The given image is of Blepharophimosis syndrome. It has the following components:

 

  • Congenital ptosis (drooping of eyelids)
  • Blepharophimosis (Narrowing of palpebral fissure)
  • Telecanthus (Increased intercanthal distance)
  • Epicanthus inversus (Fold of skin from lower lid to upper lid covering medial canthus)

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ptosis: Ptosis, or drooping of the upper eyelid, is a key component of blepharophimosis syndrome. It's often present from birth and can be significant, sometimes impairing vision.

 

Option C. Epicanthus Inversus: Epicanthus inversus is a characteristic feature of blepharophimosis syndrome. It involves a fold of skin that arises from the lower eyelid and covers the inner corner (canthus) of the eye.

 

Option D. Blepharophimosis: Blepharophimosis, the reduction in the horizontal width of the eyelids, is a defining feature of this syndrome. It results in a narrow palpebral fissure (eyelid opening).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given clinical picture shows blepharophimosis, epicanthus inversus and ptosis, indicating a diagnosis of Blepharophimosis syndrome. Exotropia is not a part of this syndrome.

 

Ref: pg 59/ eyelids/ 6th edition/ comprehensive ophthalmology ak khurana

questions.text: What is the immediate treatment at this stage of dacryocystitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Antibiotics & drainage

 

Option C:

 

  • Lacrimal sac is the small sac located in the inner corner of the eye that collects tears and drains them into the nasal cavity.
  • An infection or inflammation of this sac is called dacryocystitis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given clinical picture is suggestive of acute dacryocystitis with cellulitis and abscess formation. Thus, patient needs to be treated with systemic antibiotics and drainage of abscess.

choices.text: Basal cell carcinoma
Squamous cell carcinoma

questions.text: Identify the following lid tumour:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Basal cell carcinoma

 

Option A:

 

BASAL CELL CARCINOMA:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Malignant Melanoma: Appears as a rapidly growing pigmented lesion that can have variable colors, with an irregular border and may arise de novo or from a pre-existing mole.

 

Option C. Squamous Cell Carcinoma: Typically manifests as a scaly, erythematous, and sometimes ulcerated lesion that can be mistaken for a benign lesion but has potential for local invasion and metastasis.

 

Option D. Keratoacanthoma: Usually emerges as a dome-shaped, flesh-colored nodule with a central keratin-filled crater and may spontaneously regress over time.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given clinical image shows a pearly nodule with telangiectatic vessels, on the lower eyelid suggestive of Basal Cell Carcinoma.

 

Ref: pg 23/eyelids/kanski’s clinical ophthalmology 8th edition

questions.text: Which organism causes Blepharitis acarica?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Demodex folliculorum

 

Option C:

 

Blepharitis is a chronic inflammation of the margins of the lids, appearing as a simple hyperaemia or as a true inflammation.

 

Blepharitis acarica is caused by Demodex folliculorum (Parasite).

 

Image of Demodex folliculorum mite

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Staphylococcus epidermidis: Staphylococcus epidermidis is a part of the normal skin flora and is also found in the mucous membranes. It can be a cause of blepharitis, typically contributing to bacterial blepharitis, but is not the organism associated with Blepharitis acarica.

 

Option B: Ascaris: Ascaris refers to a genus of parasitic roundworms. Ascaris lumbricoides is the species responsible for ascariasis in humans, affecting the intestines. It is not involved in eye infections or conditions like blepharitis.

 

Option D: Propionibacterium: Propionibacterium, known as Cutibacterium, includes species such as Propionibacterium acnes, which is part of the normal skin flora and has been implicated in acne development. While it can be associated with eyelid margin inflammation, it is not the causative agent of Blepharitis acarica.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Demodex folliculorum is the organism that causes Blepharitis acarica, a condition characterized by infestation of the eyelash follicles leading to blepharitis.

 

Ref: Singh A, Acharya M, Mathur U. Commentary: Demodex - Microscopic residents of the ocular biome. Indian J Ophthalmol. 2021 Sep;69(9):2394-2395. doi: 10.4103/ijo.IJO_1137_21. PMID: 34427229; PMCID: PMC8544099.

questions.text: Identify the abnormality:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Morning glory syndrome

 

Option C:

 

The given image shows:

 

  • A large disc with a funnel-shaped excavation surrounded by a ring-shaped chorioretinal disturbance. Blood vessels emerge from the rim of excavation radially, like spokes of a wheel. Veins and arteries are difficult to distinguish.
  • Persistent hyaloid vascular remnants are seen as a white tuft of glial tissue overlying the centre.

 

All these features make the optic disc look like a morning glory flower, hence the name.

 

 

  • Morning glory anomaly may be unilateral and sporadic condition or bilateral and hereditary (rarer).
  • PAX6 gene mutation may be present.
  • The most important systemic association is frontonasal dysplasia.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. OPTIC DISC PIT: An optic disc pit is a congenital anomaly characterized by a small, round or oval, grayish depression in the optic nerve head, often associated with potential complications like serous macular detachment.

 

 

Option B: Posterior staphyloma: Posterior staphyloma is a localized protrusion or bulging of the sclera (the white outer layer of the eye) at the back of the eye, often associated with severe myopia (nearsightedness) and thinning of the scleral tissue.

 

 

Option D. Advanced glaucomatous cupping: Advanced glaucomatous cupping refers to the deepening and enlargement of the optic cup in the optic nerve head, a sign of progressive damage caused by glaucoma, leading to a distinctive cup-to-disc ratio increase and corresponding vision loss.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

Morning Glory Syndrome is a congenital, enlarged, funnel-shaped optic disc anomaly.

 

REF: KANSKI 9TH EDITION PAGE 774

choices.text: Both light reflex and near reflex intact
Both light reflex and near reflex absent
Light reflex is absent and near reflex is present
Light reflex is present and near reflex is absent

questions.text: True about Parinaud’s Syndrome:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Light reflex is absent and near reflex is present

 

Option C:

 

  • Parinaud syndrome is dorsal midbrain syndrome.
  • The Pretectal nuclei responsible for the pupillary light reflex lie more dorsally than those controlling the near reflex, making them more susceptible to compressive effects. Therefore, dorsal midbrain lesions typically result in the loss of the pupillary light reflex and, preservation of the near reflex.
  • Features:
    • Straight eyes in the primary position
    • Supranuclear up gaze and downgaze palsy on saccadic movement
    • Large pupils with light–near dissociation
    • Lid retraction (Collier sign)
    • Convergence–retraction nystagmus

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Both light reflex and near reflex intact: In Parinaud’s Syndrome, the patient typically has a problem with vertical gaze, especially upward gaze, due to a lesion in the midbrain and light-near dissociation.

 

Option B. Both light reflex and near reflex absent: This is less characteristic of Parinaud’s Syndrome.

 

Option D. Light reflex is present and near reflex is absent: This is less typical for Parinaud’s Syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most characteristic feature of Parinaud’s Syndrome is the light-near dissociation, where the pupillary light reflex is absent but the near reflex is preserved. This is due to the involvement of the pretectal area while sparing the Edinger-Westphal nucleus.

 

REF: KANSKI 9TH EDITION PAGE 807

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient who is on ATT came to the OPD with complaints of blurring of vision and impairment in colour vision. On carrying out perimetry, bilateral centrocecal scotoma is noted. Which of the following drug may be responsible?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ethambutol

 

Option C:

 

  • The scenario given above is suggestive of toxic optic neuropathy.
  • Red–green dyschromatopsia is the most common objective abnormality of colour vision, but subtle (undetectable on Ishihara testing) blue–yellow defects may be an early finding.
  • Visual loss occurs due to damage to optic nerve fibres as a result of exogenous toxins.
  • These include
    • Tobacco 
    • Ethyl alcohol
    • Methyl alcohol
    • Quinine
    • Ethambutol
  • In most cases of ethambutol induced optic neuropathy, resolution occurs following cessation of the drug.
  • Before starting the drug, visual acuity and colour vision is to be tested, and followed up every 6 months after starting.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pyrazinamide: This drug is not commonly associated with ocular side effects. It is more known for its hepatotoxicity and hyperuricemia.

 

Option B. Rifampicin: Rifampicin can cause various side effects, including liver dysfunction and hypersensitivity reactions, but it is not typically associated with the specific ocular side effects described in the question.

 

Option D. Streptomycin: Streptomycin, an aminoglycoside, is more commonly associated with vestibular and auditory side effects, such as vertigo and hearing loss, rather than with ocular side effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethambutol, an antituberculosis drug, can cause optic neuropathy leading to blurring of vision, impaired color vision, and centrocecal scotoma. This is a critical side effect to monitor for in patients on antituberculosis regimens including ethambutol.

 

REF: KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5TH EDITION pg.no: 316

questions.text: When light is flashed onto one eye, both the eyes’ pupils constrict as a response. This is known as the pupillary light reflex. Where is the center for this reflex located?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Midbrain

 

Option B:

 

  • The pupillary reflex fibres are relayed to the PRETECTAL NUCLEUS located in the midbrain.
  • Afferent: Optic Nerve
  • Efferent: Short ciliary nerves

 

 

Midbrain: The midbrain plays a crucial role in the control of eye movements, primarily through two key structures: the superior colliculi and the oculomotor nerve nuclei (cranial nerve III).

 

  1. Superior Colliculi:
    • The superior colliculi, located in the tectum of the midbrain, are involved in the initiation of saccadic eye movements. These are rapid, jerky movements of the eyes that abruptly change the point of fixation.
    • They receive visual inputs as well as inputs from other sensory modalities and are responsible for directing the eyes toward an object of interest, particularly in response to new or sudden visual stimuli.
  2. Oculomotor Nerve Nuclei:
    • The oculomotor nerve nuclei control most of the eye's movements and are responsible for the constriction of the pupil and maintaining an open eyelid.
    • They coordinate the actions of the muscles that control the movement of the eyeball and the upper eyelid. Specifically, they innervate the superior, inferior, and medial rectus muscles, the inferior oblique muscle, the levator palpebrae superioris, and the sphincter pupillae.

 

Additionally, the midbrain is involved in the integration of the vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR), which stabilizes the visual field during head movements, and the accommodation reflex.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Pons: Pontine centres are involved in optokinetic nystagmus. Pontine lesions cause dolls eye movement.

 

Option D: Cerebellum- Cerebellum is involved in integration and coordination of optokinetic nystagmus. Characteristics of cerebellar nystagmus include:

 

  1. Direction: It is typically horizontal, but can also be vertical or rotary. The direction of the nystagmus may change depending on the direction of gaze.
  2. Gaze-Evoked Nystagmus: This form of nystagmus becomes more pronounced when the patient looks to the side. It is due to the failure of the cerebellum to hold steady gaze, leading to a drift of the eyes back to the central position, followed by a corrective saccade.
  3. Intensity and Amplitude: The intensity and amplitude of the nystagmus can increase with the degree of lateral gaze and decrease or disappear with gaze towards the midline.
  4. Associated Symptoms: Patients with cerebellar nystagmus may also exhibit other signs of cerebellar dysfunction, such as ataxia, dysarthria, and tremor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand that the pupillary light reflex is mediated by the midbrain, involving an interplay between the optic and oculomotor nerves.

 

REF: PARSON’S DISEASES OF EYE PAGE 33
